overview: This measure establishes a temporary three-year women's court pilot program within the Second and Fifth Circuits. [5] It also requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit. [5] The program is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [6]
appropriations: The bill appropriates funds and establishes temporary positions. [5] The Department of Health requests a budget of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt) based on staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [5] This budget would cover a 1.0 FTE Clinical Psychologist at $145,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt), a 1.0 FTE Social Worker/Human Services Professional IV at $76,788 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt), and a 1.0 FTE Social Services Assistant V at $45,216 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt) for each circuit. [5]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Department of Health's request for a budget of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt) is based on the Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [5] It is assumed that each circuit would require a full-time clinical psychologist, social worker, and social services assistant. [5] The Judiciary notes that circumstances on the neighbor islands may warrant different implementation and different resource requirements. [5]
agency_impact: The Judiciary supports the intent of the measure but proposes amendments and modifications so that the pilot project can be successful in the Third Circuit. [5] The Judiciary's proposal calls for a Big Island Women's Court (BIWC) program to operate in both Hilo and Kona under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court. [5] The Department of Health requests funding to expand services, including staff support, to implement the program. [5]
economic_impact: The intent of the project is to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism. [5] Expansion to the other circuits would allow the program to assist more women in need and divert them away from incarceration. [5] Gender-responsive women’s courts are effective because they address the unique needs and challenges women face, such as trauma, substance use disorder, and mental illness. [5]
policy_impact: The Judiciary proposes amendments to the bill, including sufficient funding and staff to operate in both Hilo and Kona and to operate as a separate program under the supervision of Big Island Drug Court (“BIDC”). [5] Given the Third Circuit’s willingness to pilot a modified Women’s Court model, the Judiciary respectfully requests that the Second and Fifth Circuits be deleted from consideration for this pilot project. [5] The current measure, however, establishes the pilot in the Second and Fifth Circuits while requiring an interim study for the Third Circuit. [5]
revenue_sources: This measure appropriates funds. [5] The Department of Health requests that funding for this measure be considered as a vehicle to expand services, provided it does not supplant the requests outlined in the Governor's executive budget request. [5] The provided documents do not specify the source of the appropriations, such as general revenues or special funds. [5]

[5] [5] It also requires the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program there. [5] The Department of Health requests a budget of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt) based on its staffing requirements for the existing First Circuit pilot project. [5] This funding would cover staffing for each circuit, including a 1.0 FTE Clinical Psychologist at $145,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt), a 1.0 FTE Social Worker/Human Services Professional IV at $76,788 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt), and a 1.0 FTE Social Services Assistant V at $45,216 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-25-25_.PDF.txt). [5] The Judiciary notes that to be successful, the Big Island Women's Court will require sufficient funding and positions. [5] The Judiciary outlines a specific proposal for a Big Island Women’s Court (BIWC) to operate in both Hilo and Kona under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court, citing the unique geography and lack of mental health services on the island. [5] [5] Based on this alternative proposal, the Judiciary requests that the Second and Fifth Circuits be deleted from consideration for the pilot project.
